28.64.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain:
Coming up

32.16.text:
I'm here at the BSA Factory in Birmingham
looking at their Airgun chamber of horrors.

37.83.text:
We're in Scotland after a traditional MacNab.
I'm also on the River Mersey, but that's a

43.72.text:
story for Fishing Britain. We've got the regulars;
we have got Hunting Youtube, we've got Hello

49.52.text:
Charlie, we've got Hywel Morgan on a bank
in Wales. But first, lets go to the River

54.15.text: Test to find out if women attract fish.

64.10.text:
It is the Orvis day at Kimbridge on the beautiful
River Test: a place so rich and rare that

69.07.text:
bloke from Pink Floyd lives on the other bank
(36:30 Roger Waters' house). After breakfast

73.16.text:
at the lovely Bourne Valley Inn. Writers from
country magazines and even the Mail on Sunday

77.86.text:
have come here to fish for trout. So what's
going to catch trout in the River Test at

82.50.text:
the beginning of April, especially when you
are limited to upstream dry fly and nymph?

87.41.text:
The word on the street is that it has to be
shrimp. Now the moths have had a go at my

91.51.text:
fly tying box over the winter, and munched
all the pink seal fur I would normally use

96.21.text:
for that. I need something pink for shrimpety
shrimp. Where will I find pink? Ah -- the

103.56.text:
Shrimp is the way forward so I need something
pink and I was looking around for something

107.42.text: pink to tie a fly with.

108.77.text:
Oh! I wonder where we could find something
pink?

111.77.text:
Just a minute, what's this? It's my Arsenal
Red!

114.91.text:
Right it's pink enough for me. Now how are
we going to do this. Am I going to cut it

121.14.text:
off or are you?I think Laura should. No, hang
on I'll give it a go. Laura could you come

125.76.text:
over and cut it off please. That's fantastic.
There you go. Okay Claire, that is what I've

130.25.text:
got. Fantastic, oh that's alI, that's perfect!
I was worried there would be a big chunk coming

132.93.text:
out! It is a big chunk. right , I am now going
to tie a flie with your hair, thank you very

138.65.text:
It is the work of moments to tie a fly. Cue
the music I guess PR girls' hairdos don't

144.26.text:
come cheap so these trout had better appreciate
it.

147.57.text:
I think that's a good solid nine and a half
darling. It got the Arsenal Red, look, it's

154.26.text:
beautifully tied. It looks like a little Hedgehog
from that way and I am sure it's going to

159.57.text: catch you many, many trout today.

161.88.text:
She is such a Londoner. Now there is much
talk about how women are better at fishing

166.82.text:
through the magic of hormones than any ability
on their part. Certainly, hormones are hard

171.98.text:
at work on this river as these randy drakes
display.

175.71.text:
Maybe I should have asked Claire not for pink
straight hair but brown curly ones.

179.45.text:
There is a thing about pheromones attracting
salmon.There is a belief that women are very

186.43.text:
successful salmon anglers because of pheromones
attracting the fish. Whether there is any

190.72.text:
truth in it, who knows, but it's a nice thing
to believe. That said, I think, what tends

196.42.text:
to happen is women tend to be more diligent
pupils and they are much better at diligently

202.29.text:
and carefully searching the water particularly
closer and under the bank whereas men like

206.50.text:
to wade in and go charging in and cast as
far as they can, meanwhile standing on the

213.27.text: So what does the Test have to offer today?"

215.81.text:
Roach, pike,grayling and obviously trout.
I've personally caught pike to nearly twenty

222.94.text:
pounds out of here. Lovely roach, big chubs,
well over six pounds and obviously trout.

229.77.text:
The biggest that I have seen out here is probably
touching double figures. So there is some

234.59.text:
Other people are catching on shrimp-type flies
but I am not having much luck. Mail on Sunday

239.38.text:
bloke, a novice, gets into a fish. Even Wes
Stanton from The Shooting Show has landed

244.02.text:
a big grayling -- notice the mark of the cormorant
on its back -- but I am not sure he completely

249.50.text:
understands the genteel art of stalking fish
in chalk streams.

253.07.text:
I've never fished a dropper before, hence
the more than healthy number of tangles I've

259.75.text:
been getting. But, I'm kind of using it as
a bite indicater at the moment.

265.96.text:
You do realise you're going to be drummed
out of the Houghton club on five counts on

269.18.text: that last sentence alone, don't you.

271.62.text:
Back the fly that Orvis is now calling Claire's
Fancy. I try everywhere. The long slow bits,

277.10.text:
the bubbly shallow bits.
If they are not taking then go somewhere there

287.71.text:
are lots of bubbles and lots of movement.
But that doesn't work either.

296.77.text:
At last, I find a place where fish are rising.
Not big fish but fish. Then this happens.

307.73.text:
Once again in slow motion... let's call that
long-range catch-and-release. It proves, however,

313.58.text:
that you, with perseverance, catch a grayling
on Claire's hair.

318.78.text:
Hot pink shrimp, peri-peri-shrimp, wear it
in her ear.

319.95.text:
I offer Orvis the rights to produce the fly
and sell it to the mass market, but they tactfully

323.95.text: point out they don't want a bald PR girl.

327.03.text:
That just goes to show that when you get to
a river like this, where the trout are whiley,

332.84.text: don't try anything new or never trust a lady.

336.58.text:
For more about Orvis, both for fishing kit
and for fishing at Kimbridge, go to Orvis.co.uk

346.09.text:
From lady gardens to man mountains, lets go
to David on the Fieldsports Channel News Stump.

360.38.text:
Brian May is back -- and he is speaking out
against bird shooting.

367.71.text:
Viewer Ryan Vella from Malta sends us this
video of the 66-year-old guitarist stopping

372.46.text:
a performance in Malta to get political, telling
the audience what he thinks about birds and

377.49.text:
of course badgers...we love you Brian.
The results are in for the big farmland bird

385.91.text:
count.
The RSPB holds the Big Garden Birdwatch as

389.35.text:
a major post-Christmas fundraiser, and it
tells alarming stories, such as the 84% decline

395.16.text:
in starling numbers since 1979. The Game & Wildlife
Conservation Trust runs the Big Farmland birdwatch

401.83.text:
across more than half a million acres of land,
and it tells the real story. For example,

407.21.text:
starlings are Britain's most abundant farmland
bird. RSPB, go to the bottom of the class.

412.84.text:
George Digweed continues his flying form in
shooting competitions, winning the Essex Masters.

420.03.text:
After a dramatic shoot-off against Tim Webster,
he retained the Masters trophy, which he's

426.37.text:
now won six times.
There's an internet forum for shooters in

431.24.text:
Northern Ireland that's gathering pace. Shoot-NI.com
was started in November 2012 and now has members

437.75.text:
province wide. Viewer Jonny Copey asks for
a shout-out.

442.89.text:
The success of hunting tourism in Belarus
has led to increased penalties for poaching.

448.29.text:
Fines for killing a deer are now nearly £1,000.
In 2013, hunting sector revenues brought in

454.93.text:
around £10 million, with foreign tourism
generating almost half of this amount. Most

460.50.text:
visitors come from Russia, followed by the
Czech Republic, Slovenia and Germany. Here's

464.49.text:
a flavour of it, put up last month by YouTuber
Lubomir Atanassov

469.74.text:
And finally here's a children's take on hunting
-- If you haven't seen them before on Youtube

475.82.text:
Kids Snippets cover all sorts of topics from
job interviews to beauty pageants -- in this

480.69.text:
one they are stalking and talking to a reindeer
-- Roy Lupton uses a very similar technique.

486.47.text:
You are up to date with Fieldsports Channel
News, Stalking the stories, fishing for facts!

Now lets look at what you lot have been up
to, it is Hallo Charlie!

Hello Charlie, Mark Yaley here,out in the

Love the show. Want to say a hello to my brother
Andy in Canada. He loves the show too.

Hallo Charlie, this is Jason Doyle from Ireland
in Yorkshire with Pete Carr with the Buck

Hello Charlie, this is some Roe stalking in
Somerset and this is the first buck on the

536.36.text:
Hello Charlie, Jamie here from rural Hertfordshire.
Been pigeon shooting on the oilseed rape again.

Send us you're own Hello Charlie, film yourself

Hello Charlie, who you are and what you're

560.06.text:
Now we're in Scotland after a traditional
McNab:

565.89.text:
Ahhh -- you can almost smell the peat. We're
on the Rottal estate at Glen Clova in Scotland.

572.72.text:
It's mid September and the midgies are hungry.
We've been invited on a bit of a Macnab -- that's

588.33.text:
red stag, salmon and grouse in one day. We
have been lucky enough to have been asked

592.94.text:
to film a few of these, and with some incredible
success, but this one gets scuppered in the

604.39.text:
first few hours as the water is so low on
the south Esk that there's more chance of

608.95.text:
catching a mud skipper...
So it's on to the main event -- the red stag

613.31.text:
stalking. Alex Mackenzie-Smith is the man
charged with keeping some level of sporting

619.67.text: pride and Donald is the man with the knowledge.

623.05.text:
There's a peat bump maybe 150 yards away,
we'll get to that and see what we can see.

Up here every day supplies the stalker with
a different challenge -- this afternoon it's

634.31.text:
the stillness of the day which means the midgies
are able to make an even greater nuisance

He guided me in to within about almost exactly
150 yards and we identified the beast, which

649.76.text:
was a good young beast. Very nice beast who
had shed all its velvet and it was lying down

658.79.text:
having it's afternoon Siesta and we lay there
for, the the prone position over the rifle,

663.98.text: we lay there for almost exactlly 50 minutes.

667.43.text: Which wasn't great with all the midgies around.

670.73.text:
Which was, no, absolutely, we got eaten alive
and I still have the marks all along my lips

to show for it. But it was just an awesome
stalk and finally the beast began to move

683.95.text:
and Fred stood up and a good clean shot exactly
where required and then actually,interestingly

enough actually, the whole 87 beasts took
off down the hill, Fred included and quite

surprisingly it took us a little while to

dropped and it was a good clean kill and it
was really excellent and great fun and all

707.49.text:
credit to Donald the Ghille for doing a wonderful
job for me. That was just the middle of a

715.08.text:
Estate owner Dee Ward comes with Alex. He
and Alex are neighbours and were hoping to

719.17.text:
complete the full MacNab of a salmon, brace
of grouse and a staggie but a day's sport

724.06.text:
is a day's sport and Alex has bagged a perfect
beast. Even though he was eaten alive during

726.42.text: the hour it took for the shot to present itself.

727.71.text:
On the descent, Dee and Alex can have a go
at the grouse shooting. The numbers are good

735.40.text:
When I took over eight or nine years ago,
we had very few grouse. They hadn't shot for

739.93.text:
a few years. But we really stuck to the basics
and they are: putting a lot of grit out, we've

746.94.text:
used medicated grit which helps obviously
to keep the grouse healthy. We've burnt a

751.50.text:
lot of heather and we've killed a lot of vermin.
Those are the three main things. Especially

756.52.text:
things like stoats and weasels. They will
destroy a nest and they can do a lot of damage.

762.14.text:
So, by reducing the amount of stoats and weasels
as well as things like hooded crows and the

767.70.text: like.l That's made a big difference.

769.67.text:
Dee connects with a left and right -- and
the gents have their grouse. If he had grassed

a salmon, Alex would have persevered with
trying to shoot a brace of birds but the MacNab

778.80.text:
will have to wait for another day and we don't
want to tempt fate given the date.

783.88.text:
Friday, the 13th of September and it's lucky
for some. I got a stag but not lucky in terms

of getting the whole Mcnab but a wonderful
day.

793.45.text:
Friday the 13th claimed this MacNab but it
certainly didn't spoil the Scottish experience.

So Richard, if their is one thing the air

Basically make sure all the seals on your

Bisely oil. A tiny little drop to make sure

you work the components a little bit and that
